A flying saucer crew of 20 male space explorers travels millions of light years to check on a colony founded 25 years ago on a 'forbidden planet.' They find an advanced robot, a socially inept young woman, and her hermit philologist father haunted by ancient civilization demons. This pulp scifi murder mystery is sometimes compared to The Tempest but serves as a cautionary tale about technology and progress. Despite some dated effects, its special effects and aesthetics are impressive. While not the best 1950s sci-fi, it's a must-see for fans, featuring a plot inspiring shows like Star Trek. Stand-out performances come from Anne Francis, Earl Holliman, and Robby the Robot, though Nielsen's and Pigeon's roles suffer from direction issues.

This docudrama on the Lindy Chamberlain case examines its impact on Australian society and the role of innuendo and expectations in real-life dramas. It addresses the expectation of uniform emotional responses and criticizes media for seeking dramatic reactions. The leads and a large supporting cast, including comic actors, play their roles with depth and sensitivity. I, an ex-Adventist in Australia during the incident, find the story handled with creativity, personality, and emotional heart, especially the scene with the news choppers. Fred Schepsi advised actors to "play the best case for their character," a principle applicable to all acting.

In this dark film, a young, poor student sells his soul to the devil for money, losing his mirror image. This symbolizes internal conflict and impending doom. While he enjoys wealth, the pact makes love unattainable. Haunted by his double, he is cut off from society, becoming like a hunted animal. The film’s scenes and tragic finale make it one of the best, despite its early, occasionally clumsy execution. Paul Wegener, the actor and director, is praised, and understanding its historical context and German doppelganger tradition enhances appreciation.

Despite my interest in Babbage’s difference engine and related subjects, I found the film amateurish and plodding. The outdated graphics and improbable concepts, like reconstructing past information via software and predictive computing, detracted from its believability. The sci-fi angle didn’t suit Ada’s story, which would benefit from a straightforward biographical approach. Moreover, technical inaccuracies, like the unrealistic mouse-clicking representation, undermined the film’s credibility. Though it’s unique like "Pi," these flaws overshadowed my enjoyment, resulting in a 3/10 rating.

I loved the movie on Turner yesterday! Despite predictable moments, Farrell excelled, and the cast did a great job. Some parts were a stretch, but it was touching. If you're a mom, you'll relate. Loretta was stunning. WATCH IT if you can!
How was the quirky British movie about Judi Dench's character rounding up an all-girl band from wartime London?
What are your thoughts on Takashi Miike's approach to dark fairy tales in his film for children?
Can you comment on this tale of romance and intrigue, and its music? Another movie I liked later was High Society with Bing Crosby. Thanks, Florence Forrester-Stockton, Reno, Nevada
Wild drum scene! Cook, Jr. shines as unsung hero. Fantastic actor, great flick, with twists. Must-see.
Why was this movie so horrible?
Why was I disappointed with Busby Berkeley's film starring James Cagney?

My favorite horror film. From the first tracking shot to the final twist, this is Carpenter's masterpiece.

Halloween night 1963, Michael Meyers murders his sister. Halloween 1978, Michael escapes and murders again.

The story is simple: Michael stalks and kills babysitters. It's Carpenter's atmosphere of dread that generates the tension. Events are telegraphed but still surprise.

Dark lighting, long steady-cam shots, and eerie music create claustrophobic scenes. The body count is small, and most murders are nearly bloodless. The fear is in the unknown.

The acting is good. PJ Soles provides humor, Nancy Loomis turns in a decent performance, and Jamie Leigh-Curtis is perfectly cast as the shy lead, not prepared for the horror she faces. Donald Pleasence is excellent as Dr. Sam Loomis. Rest in peace Mr. Pleasence.

The film's flaw is the passage of time. Many clones and imitators have diluted its power. But, viewed as it once was, it's unique.

Highly recommended. 10/10
What are your thoughts on the film you saw 10 years ago, written by John Hughes, that stands out for its garish look and unique cast?
How do you interpret the film HUNDSTAGE in terms of its portrayal of working-class lives and its emotional impact?
How does "The Straight Story" differ from typical David Lynch films?
Did Amitabh and other actors really believe their performances in Aag could better the original Sholay?
Why is this Stephen King-derived film too brightly modern and lacking in atmosphere, despite Alice Kridge's strong performance?
Anyone mention the opening scene with a butcher knife through a wig in the front yard?
How would you summarize your experience watching "D-War: Dragon Wars"?
How did this movie maintain suspense throughout despite any flaws?
How did cultural differences impact the plot and characters of the 1986 film 'Gung Ho'?

Why do Polynesians have South American-like traditions and features? Why does South American vegetation resemble Polynesian flora? Why do islanders speak of South American ancestors? Why do Norwegians talk about ancestors leaving South America westward?

I've been a Seagal fan for 25 years and seen all his films. Why is his voice dubbed in this movie with a thin, whiny imposter's voice? And why is his real voice used for some lines but not others? The Seagal in this movie lacks the swagger, confidence, and charm he had before. Where's his signature attitude and charisma? Is this film an indication that the Seagal we loved is gone?

The Dentist is a twisted story about Dr. Feinstone, a clean-cut dentist whose life spirals out of control. After finding out his wife is cheating and facing IRS trouble, he begins to harm patients. Directed by Brian Yuzna and produced by Pierre David, it features strong performances, especially by Corbin Bernsen as the psycho dentist. The film stars Linda Hoffman, Micahel Stadvec, Ken Foree, and Virginya Keehne. If you fear dentists, you might want to skip this dark, humor-filled movie.

I'm a big Randolph Scott fan, but this film is a dud. It feels fake with awful rear-screen projection. A good plot is buried in a bad script, making it hard to care about the characters. The directing is pedestrian and highlights the script's flaws. Despite Scott's charm, the film is just not enjoyable. Ms. Wymore is beautiful and talented, but her lines and blocking were bad. Phil Carey plays an unlikeable character well. Comic relief falls flat. The two Spanish songs were enjoyable, but that's not why we watch Randolph Scott movies. This film is mediocre, not unbearable but far from great.

"It's all about the family." Worst line ever in a "horror" movie, although this isn't even horror. Owen Wilson is a better actor and should stop playing the token guy who dies (Anaconda, Armageddon). He co-wrote "Bottle Rocket" and "Rushmore" and has talent. Lily Taylor belongs in indie films, not here. Catherine Zeta-Jones should switch to porn; no place in legitimate acting. One of the worst movies I've ever seen.

The only real highlight is the sniveling guy's death and the surviving characters' reaction. This film is a lame rip-off of Jaws, Lake Placid, and Alligator, with a bit of Godzilla (1998). The non-starring females undress at least once; the female lead doesn't. The plot centers on filming "blood surfing," an extreme sport in shark-infested waters, alongside a giant salt-water crocodile. People get eaten. The movie ends. It's a dull bad horror movie.

I can't remember many details about the show, but I was passionate about it and determined not to miss any episodes. Without a VCR, I haven't seen it since, but I remember feeling thrilled every time it came on. Sam Waterstone was my favorite actor and still is, mostly because of this series. I would do anything to see it again and revisit my childhood. Any ideas where I can find it or has someone taped it from the first airing?

"Hitler, the Rise of Evil" offers a refreshing take on Hitler's corrupt rise to power, ending with his peak. The film, set authentically in the 1930s and featuring standout performances like Peter O'Toole as von Hindenburg, is compelling. My copy includes a second DVD with two documentaries on Hitler's personality and the 1983 Hitler-diaries forgery scandal.

Rachel York was fantastic as "Lucy." Having seen her in "Kiss Me, Kate" and "Victor/Victoria," I appreciate her versatile characterizations. Critics focus too much on her not looking like Lucy. I wasn't after an impersonation; I wanted depth, which Rachel delivered. She nailed the routines, particularly in the Grape Stomping scene. The rehearsal approach for classic sketches was innovative. Rachel captured Lucy's progression brilliantly, showing a natural development. She skillfully portrayed Lucy's complexity and deserves more great roles and an Emmy.

As a former submariner, this was one of the worst submarine movies I have seen. A mutiny aboard a US Naval vessel, especially a Nuclear Powered Trident submarine, is unthinkable. These men are dedicated to their mission. I could never see a crew split their alliance between the Captain and Executive Officer like in this film. An Executive Officer like the one Denzel Washington played would be relieved and court-martialed. The Navy didn't send a technical adviser for this film, no surprise. The noise levels portrayed are unrealistic; submariners learn to be as quiet as possible. Loud music is never tolerated. This depiction is over-the-top and ridiculous. I would not recommend this movie.

`Europa' ('Zentropa') is visually stunning with seamless grayscale and color photography. It competed for the 1991 Golden Palm against Barton Fink by the Coen brothers. Rent both and judge for yourself.

Not a very good movie but accurate in depicting torture techniques. The film effectively shows the brutality of the NK POW camps with surprising frankness for the time. Despite technical flaws, it unveils a forgotten corner of a forgotten war. It contrasts with later Vietnam films, reflecting an evolving cinematic treatment of war, seen similarly in "Pork Chop Hill" and differing from "Go Tell The Spartans".

Towards the end of this thriller, Ally Sheedy's latter-day image creates a hauntingly evil effect, suggesting she could excel in a Bette Davis-type role. However, there aren't many other reasons to watch. Sally Kirkland's character is tiresome, and the tension sags during her scenes. Savage's character is distasteful but has a small role. Nicholas Walker's acting is wooden and uninspiring, while Dara Tomanovich improves the level in her scenes with Sheedy. Although Sheedy delivers a meticulous performance, it's often out of context. The sets are drab, and the camera work is undistinguished.

It's a ghost, cannibalism, and revenge story, but poorly done with much violence. It follows the usual slasher movie formula: isolated place, cocky campers in the wilderness. Intense scenes exist, but it's dull with bad editing. Ghost children sound odd, and it's unclear what rules the ghosts and psycho follow. Includes a gross scene of a man eating his wife's remains. It's gratuitous violence with no cleverness, just a waste of time. Lots of blood; little plot.
Worst movie Adam's ever done; used fast forward. Don't waste your time. I saw it to complete his filmography, but it sucked.

As a Film studies graduate, I've seen a range of films, but 'Summer Rain' is the worst. Hoping for a British classic, my flatmates and I ended up laughing at the ridiculous acting and cheesy script. The main characters, Michelle and Gary, were annoying and unlikable. I regret paying £3 for this. Avoid at all costs.

This is one of the most idiotic films ever made. It's about cruise ship waiter Shecky (Sandler) wanting to be a comedian. There isn't one funny or clever line in the entire movie. It's so unfunny it's pathetic. There isn't much crude or sexual humor, but the f-word is plentiful. The budget is really low, ruining the film. It seems they only rented a small boat with 10 extras, including Billy Bob Thornton. The opening credits are cheaply animated. I hate this movie, and others will too. 86 mins. rated R for Language.
Fight scenes are slow-motion Jackie Chan, wit attempts are pathetic. Stars: Brandon Lee has charisma, Dolph Lundgren lacks it. Director: Avoid love scenes if relying on body doubles. (*1/2)
Another exercise in self-importance from kids who never really grew up.

Despite being dated, this timeless and funny underdog tale has Buster fighting unkindly odds in the Stone, Roman, and Modern Ages, showing early comedic depictions of cavemen and Roman gladiators. Themes reflect the unchanged struggles of winning love from prehistoric times to 1923. Watching it now highlights dramatic changes over eighty years.

This movie sucks. The concept of a machine transforming matter to energy is intriguing. However, they break the machine instead of exploring its potential. Lembach leaving leads to a botched reattempt, resulting in the doctor killing people. The subplot with two professors is dull. If they hadn't broken the machine, it might have been better. I give it 2 stars for effort. Damn you, Lembach!

Great times with the Quiroz Brothers and cast on this project as the "Guy on the Bench." They captured a true "B" horror film well. I hope to work with Pumpkin Patch Pictures again. After moving to Detroit, I've been recognized in public. Once, a girl at a video store almost lost her mind and I signed her receipt. At Blockbuster, I learned our movie rented more than Ring2 at the time. The title draws interest in urban markets, and many customers didn't return it. Watch out for zombies in the hood! – Jaysun Barr (Guy on the Bench-2005)

A flying saucer manned by about 20 male space explorers travels millions of light years to a colony founded 25 years ago on a 'forbidden planet.' They find an advanced robot, a socially inept young woman, and her hermit father, a haunted philologist. Despite comparisons to Shakespeare's Tempest, this scifi murder mystery is a cautionary tale about progress and technology, with a hopeful outlook akin to Star Trek.

Anne Francis and special effects enhance the film, overcoming uninspired directing and uneven acting. It's a must-see for scifi fans, with clever plot elements reused in shows like Star Trek, though 1950s sexism and lack of racial integration are notable issues. Leslie Nielsen's performance is average, with standout roles for Ms. Francis, Earl Holliman, and Robby the Robot. Performance issues stem more from the director and editor.

I wish I could give this GARBAGE a zero, but since I can't, here's a 1 to warn you about how terrible this cartoon is! The characters look like they were drawn by pre-schoolers, and "Misadventures of Flapjack" is much better. It's a total RIP OFF, failing even at copying ideas from Dexter's Lab and Pokémon. One character is a cheap imitation of Mandark from Dexter's Lab. Mister Fellows should be sued for statutory infringement. If you like Johnny (RIP-OFF) Test, you're lying to yourself. Change the channel!

Ecstasy (1933) Starring Hedy Lamarr (as Hedy Kiesler)

The world's first glimpse of 19-year-old Hedy Lamarr occurs in this 1930's treasure as she sweeps across the screen in a wedding gown, marking the start of her legendary career. Eva (Lamarr) realizes her marital mistake on her wedding night, with her older husband uninterested in her. Gustav Machaty captures her beauty and talent with stunning camera work. Lamarr, in a shocking nude scene, dives into a lake, scandalizing but captivating audiences. Eva meets a young man, leading to a controversial but beautifully depicted romance. Her performance gained worldwide fame and caught the eye of Louis B Mayer. The film takes unexpected turns, making for a compelling story and a remarkable debut. Highly recommended for its restored DVD, it's a memorable early treasure. www.tccandler.com - TC Candler's Movie Reviews!!!

While the main plot is potentially good, unrelated subplots, multiple bad guys, double-crosses, and poorly developed characters make this film too broad. We see more of a couple having sex than the President and his mistress. The ending is incomplete, leaving no explanation for characters' actions. Surprisingly, many good actors agreed to this hollow movie. Feels like a college project. Don't waste your time unless for a film class example of what not to do.

This is the worst film I've ever watched. Couldn't sit through it. The writer's focus on women peeing, puking, and crapping was bizarre. Disgusted at wasting £4. Terrible picture and sound, non-existent acting. Scenes were like 2 girls 1 cup. Avoid at all costs! The girls seemed to be cast just for taking their tops off. Their shrieking was terrible. Like a bad amateur school production, mainly set in a car. Definitely not one to buy. Couldn't find anything positive. Hope to save someone else from wasting their money.

Perfect movies are rare, and even favorites have flaws. This film, however, is perfectly executed from start to finish. The script is brilliant, the acting superb (especially Reese Witherspoon and Sam Waterston), the directing and photography inspired, and the music score touching without being intrusive. Every sad moment is moving, every light moment makes me smile. One of the best films I've ever seen. I wish Reese Witherspoon's recent films were as serious as this one, which is about real people, feelings, and problems. Brilliant! A must-see.

The portrayal of 'indians' in this movie is stereotyped and wrong. Elvis looks good, but his skin color changes and the makeup is obvious and bad. The movie has a typically lame story and mediocre songs, like all of Elvis' later films. Colonel Parker made Elvis do them for money. It's nice to see actors like Joan Blondell and Burgess Meredith, but Meredith's makeup is awful. Elvis made a few good films like 'Love Me Tender' and 'Jailhouse Rock', but the bad ones outnumber the good. I'll always love Elvis!

Saw the movie last night, thought it was too long and not funny. Scenes included a fiancé hitting his girlfriend and beatings. Some parts, like the lady singing, felt out of place. Perry, you can do better!

This is the movie that made me appreciate Michael Keaton's talent. He delivers a brilliant parody of someone mimicking James Cagney, brimming with charm. The supporting cast excels in this '80s comedy spoofing '30s-'40s gangster movies with original material. Highlights include Joe Piscopo's hilarious taglines, Roman Moronie's unique use of profanity, and memorable sight gags like Johnny Kelly pricing puppies. It includes the best "warning against sex" film and a creative misuse of church Latin. Maureen Stapleton's unexpected gags are also a treat. If a joke misses, another will land soon. Despite minor flaws, it's likely the best spoof ever made.

The team did a great job given their £300,000 budget and 7-week timeframe. Though not for the masses due to its content, the film is a heart-wrenching tragedy that elicits deep sadness, especially for Heaton's unreturned love. One of my favorite British films that deserves more recognition.

Domino is a breath of fresh air in cinema. The intricate plot, varied characters, and intense camera effects make it unique. Some criticize the camera work, but it's intentional, showing how Domino sees things. The story, though messy to some, is a rapid form of storytelling. If you focus, it's not hard to follow. The cast is excellent, portraying unique characters effectively. Critics may not see it the same way, but it's a great film regardless.

Once, in charming France, people were happy. Men loved war; women were easy. Amid the Seven Year's War, Fanfan (Gerard Philipe) escapes marriage and enlists in the Regiment d'Aquitane, believing a gypsy's prophecy of fame and marrying the King's daughter. Adeline (Gina Lollobrigida), daughter of the recruiting sergeant, soon loves Fanfan. The film is full of irreverence, swordfights, romantic escapades, and joyous antics. Gerard Philipe, an iconic actor who died at 36, dazzles as Fanfan, while Lollobrigida shines as Adeline. The movie is a satirical take on war, with witty dialogue and pointed humor. Though once dismissed by New Wave critics like Truffaut, it’s recognized as well-made and appreciated by many. Viva Fanfan!

I regret watching the whole series. The final episode contradicted the previous seven years and ruined everything. Captain Janeway reduces a 23-year journey to seven years. Why not less? Why save only Seven of Nine? The most absurd part was the crew saying the journey mattered more than getting home. The finale showed them near Earth with no follow-up on their return. Worst ending ever.

There should be a sub-genre called 'the Robert Mitchum Western'. Mitchum's brilliant, undervalued Westerns bring his film noir persona, creating dark, compelling characters and an elegiac weariness. 'Man with the Gun' is one of his best. Directed by Orson Welles protege Richard Wilson, it features stark, monochrome beauty, chilling silhouettes, and savage violence as Mitchum tames a town terrorized by a monopolist with a private army. Mitchum's regression from soft-spoken stranger to deranged murderer is a marvel of expressive acting.

I love it. It became a phenomenon during its run. The Anorexic Twins became popular. Bob Saget started making a paycheck, and people knew Dave Coulier. Life was good and simple. One of the great American classics, it was humorous and taught good lessons. I liked the last few seasons. Like Home Improvement, older children provided more script opportunities. It could have lasted longer. I gave it an 8/10 for its wholesome, funny storylines, and Bob Saget!

Wow! A movie you could watch ten times and still delight in its nuances. Absolutely incredible! Visconti's debut film Ossessione was electrifyingly sensual and had some of the best, most genuine and realistic performances up to its date. Despite being made in 1943 and banned by Mussolini, it stands out as one of the best and most beautiful movies I've ever seen. Watch it if you can!

I am Black American and loved this soap opera. I watched it dubbed in Spanish on Telemundo 5-7 years ago. The story was about a black slave's love affair with a white commander leading to her candid, whimsical leadership.

We could learn from XICA. She saw her possibilities despite having nothing. Some argue she sold herself out, but she aimed to secure her future.

This excellent soap opera hasn't been released on DVD. It's playing on Azteca America now, but we need it back on Telemundo or on DVD.

This film is in my top four all time. James Cameron proves he's a master storyteller with movies like Aliens, The Abyss, and Terminator. Titanic stands out for its emotional depth and character development in a well-known story. Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet shine as Jack and Rose, making it their story alone. The music, by James Horner, is iconic. Despite some cheesy dialogue, Cameron delivers a romantic epic that takes you on a lifetime journey.
This is one of the worst movies ever. Shaq should stick to basketball. It wasted my time, and I'll mock it forever. It's so bad, even MST3000 would love it.

Ooof! This one was a stinker, definitely not between Star Wars and Thriller. It feels like a low-budget Wham! video with many close-ups of crying teens. Simon Le Bon preens, while the band mimics Roxy Music. Barbarella clips add nothing. Avoid, but 'Hungry Like The Wolf' part was amusing, despite the tiger-woman confusion. A DVD of Duran Duran’s '80s videos is worth a look for nostalgia.

A surprisingly light touch for a 1950s culture-clash film with John Wayne. He played a more passive role than usual and succeeded with style, showing subtlety in his acting. Despite his presence, Wayne didn't dominate the movie. The story focused on American attempts to gain favor with isolationist Japan, featuring political intrigue and well-executed cultural ceremonies. The fractured romance between Wayne and the geisha added depth, preventing the film from being purely political. The script was well-done with ample Japanese dialogue that didn't disrupt the narrative. Unlike other films, authentic-looking Orientals were cast. Overall, I enjoyed this more than similar movies and found it favorably comparable to Wayne's popular works. Recommended.

Harem Suare is the best 2000 film. Bravo Ferzan Ozpetek. Sensually shot and stunningly portrayed, it boldly tackles interracial romance, taboo in Hollywood. Women of all shapes and colors, cut off from the world, entertain each other with stories of intrigue, rivalry, and jealousy.

For a film with little publicity, this was pretty good. It's a quirky British crime film like "Snatch" and "Sexy Beast," though not as wild. It features rough characters and has a corny, somewhat predictable ending, but early twists keep it interesting. It's about a British man who gets a Russian mail-order bride, leading to surprises with her male friends. Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman co-star, alongside Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz. Kidman proves she's more than just a pretty face.

SCARECROW is a frustratingly bad B-movie. A bullied high school student is killed by his mom's boyfriend and his soul enters a scarecrow, which then kills his bullies and teachers with snappy one-liners and Matrix-like flips. The scarecrow oddly resembles a rotted corpse. Not worth watching, like its sequels.

Kenneth Branagh ambitiously undertook a full-text filmed version of 'Hamlet,' making it accessible without dumbing it down. The 19th-century European setting keeps focus on the work, and the production design and cinematography are outstanding for a four-hour movie. Branagh's inspired casting and acting excel, transforming this into a movie rather than just a deluxe play. Despite some moments where Branagh may ham it up, he makes Hamlet's thoughts and feelings clear. Many performances, notably Kate Winslet's Ophelia, are superb. However, Jack Lemmon's performance falters. The movie feels a bit lengthy with some monologues and conversations dragging on. Despite minor flaws, Branagh's 'Hamlet' stands as a potentially definitive film version.

Roy Rogers and company aim to revive "Sintown," a ghost town with potential silver mining. Andy Devine ("Cookie") provides slapstick, while Jane Frazee (Carol) catches Rogers' eye. Foy Willing and the Riders of the Purple Sage replace Bob Nolan and the Sons of the Pioneers. James Finlayson adds to the slapstick, and a loose floorboard highlights the comedy. Despite energetic performances, the material isn't exceptional.

What's the point of this movie? It's 90 minutes of confusion with unlikable characters and a nonexistent script. The "Victorian story" is laughable, with scenes of people just staring at each other. The plot involves awkward dialogue between models and a useless real estate agent. Characters are irritating, and the deaths are poorly portrayed. Plot holes abound, with a guy claiming to have witnessed events he couldn't possibly have seen. The movie finishes with a contradictory ending and is ultimately stupid and pointless. "Hell's Threshold" more belongs in purgatory. 2/10.
After losing his herd, a trail boss ends up in the Yukon gold fields with a bad reputation. His fortunes improve until past troubles resurface. Good western with many favorite old faces.

Loopy mob boss Vic (Richard Dreyfuss), released from a mental hospital, faces attempts on his life by fellow criminals including "Brass Balls" Ben (Gabriel Byrne), Jake Parker (Kyle MacLachlan), and "Wacky" Jacky (Burt Reynolds). Hit-man Mickey Holliday (Jeff Goldblum) gets caught in the chaos. Writer/director Larry Bishop delivers a dark, quirky comedy with rich performances by Ellen Barkin, Henry Silva, Gregory Hines, Diane Lane, Billy Drago, and Christopher Jones. Cameos by Billy Idol, Michael J. Pollard, Joey Bishop, Rob Reiner, and Richard Pryor add flair. Byrne's duet with Paul Anka and a climactic Mexican stand-off are highlights. Frank Byers' cinematography, nutty dialogue, and a jazzy score enhance this unique, entertaining film.

Despite its box office failure, this is my favorite film with a powerful family message. It has a lot of violence and a song with girls in bikinis. The action scenes are more realistic than other Bollywood films. Akshay Kumar and Amitabh Bachchan's combination is incredible, with Amitabh portraying an Indian Godfather. Critics are ignorant; this movie mixes comedy, romance, drama, and especially realistic action. If you want action more realistic than Main Hoon Na, this is the movie.
As a Burt Reynolds fan, this one really stinks. The dialogue is laughable and the only interesting plot twist is in the last five minutes. Can't believe he made this. Is he that hard up for money?
AWFUL!!! Starts OK but goes downhill mid-way. Anti-climactic ending with lots of gore. For schlock horror fans. 3/10

Hedy Lamarr, known for her beauty, stars as a young 20-year-old in this 1932/3 classic. A 1990 uncensored version showcases her briefly bare, but the film uses creative shots to avoid explicit content. It's visually and symbolically rich, with minimal dialogue, relying on expressionist imagery and gestures. The story is about a young girl trapped in a loveless marriage with an older man, leading to her finding romance with another. Despite 70-year-old sound quality, the film's lyrical and minimalist style stands out. It's a visual treat beyond its provocative title. I rated it 7/10.

This docudrama explores the Lindy Chamberlain case and its impact on Australian society, highlighting issues of innuendo, gossip, and emotional expectations. It challenges the notion that everyone should react the same way to crises, a concept especially relevant for journalists seeking emotional scenes for ratings. The lead actors deliver their roles with depth and sensitivity, supported by a large cast, including comic actors who excel in quick character impressions. As an ex-Adventist present during the incident, I found the story creative and emotionally resonant, particularly the scene where the couple is besieged by news choppers. Fred Schepsi’s direction for actors to "play the best case for their character" enhances the realism.

"Love in the Time of Money" is a classy film with whimsical music and explores a chain of tenuous relationships. It follows nine unhappy individuals, starting and ending with a street whore and her client. The lack of a strong story received criticism, but I found the character studies captivating. Use caution; I may be the only one who really liked it. (B)

I expected a comedy like the "Big Mama" movies. Instead, it was a bizarre mix of comedy, drama, and a love story with three plots: Madea taking in a foster child, a woman engaged to an abusive rich man, and a single mother with two kids and a single father. There's very little comedy and some twisted messages, like Madea beating the foster child to convince her to change, which she does. The movie includes child rape plots, old men ogling young relatives, and disjointed scenes leaving you off-balance—a waste of time and money.

This waste of production money proves the rich and famous can be as wasteful as politicians. Based on a play by Tennessee Williams, directed by Joseph Losey, and starring Taylor, Burton, and Noel Coward, the film's Mediterranean mansion setting is spectacular. However, a screeching Taylor, a half-asleep Burton, loony dialogue, Noel Coward's self-mockery, a ridiculous story, annoying plot devices, and absurd costuming irritate the viewer. BOOM is a disgraceful waste of money and talent—terrible and shocking.

I've loved Pushing Daisies from the start. Bryan Fuller has remarkable ideas for this wonderfully creative and original show. Compared to newer similar shows like Scrubs and House, Pushing Daisies stands out. With a magnificent cast, wonderful script, and hilarity in every episode, it’s one of the most remarkable shows on TV.

Peeew this stinks! It's based on some Geico commercials; why?! Those commercials were amusing at best; not series material. The talking Geico gecko would be better! ABC even bought the cavemen character rights from Geico for this. The cavemen struggling in the modern world isn’t unique; Phil Hartman did it on SNL as Unfrozen Caveman Lawyer. This concept works best sporadically. A regular series? No way. A 1960s series "It's About Time" did the same and lasted one season. One director, also behind the commercials, thought they had bigger stories to tell. Wrong. This will join "Me and the Chimp" as one of the all-time worst. The lead actor in that show went into hiding after it was canceled. Likely, our cavemen friends will too.

Born Again is an okay episode of Season 1. The reincarnation part is cool, but it won't rise above 'Very Good' for me. Memorable as the reincarnation episode. Good: Origami, nice fish tank, thrown out of a window. Bad: Marry best friend's wife, random reincarnation, why not remove the scarf? Conclusion: Okay, not very memorable. 7/10

A man has a nightmare as the film opens, set in dystopic 2054 Paris. It follows a woman into a club, leading to a confrontation, a kidnapping, and introduces Karas, a hard-boiled cop. Renaissance, a motion-capture-animated sci-fi noir, tells a detective story with classic film noir elements. Its harsh monochrome visual style is unique, starting from a black frame and using pitch-white highlights. Characters resemble those from a Gothic comic book but appear human in their responses and expressions. Unlike many innovative animations, Renaissance, made for $19 million over six years, balances its visual style with substantive themes of life and death, leaving a lasting impression.

One strange film, it feels like the bond company had to step in. No credits—understandably, given the stilted acting and erratic plot. Seems like missing footage and cheap, ill-fitting library music. Very odd. I'd consider a DVD if it explained what happened.

After being sentenced to 10-40 years for a drug bust and staying silent about her accomplices, Jackie (Erica Gavin) adapts to life in prison in Jonathan Demme's early film. It's a tawdry, watchable, and fun guilty pleasure, ranking just below "Silence of the Lambs" and "Stop Making Sense" but way above Demme's other movies. While it doesn't parody the Women In Prison genre, it does have flaws like the drawn-out 'untalent show' and underused Barbera Steele. My Grade: B- 

DVD Extras: 5-minute Roger Corman interview; Cast & crew Bios; Original Trailer; Trailers for "Candy Stripe Nurses" (with nudity), "Big Bad Mama 2", "Big Doll House" (with nudity), & "Crazy Mama"

Eye Candy: Juanita Brown, Cheryl "Rainbeaux" Smith, Erica Gavin, Roberta Collins, Ella Reid, Lynda Gold, and others show skin

FORBIDDEN PLANET is a top Hollywood SF film with lasting influence. It feels dated due to mid-fifties audience targeting and sluggish pacing. However, the compelling story about the Krell civilization and "monsters from the Id" remains relevant. The current DVD quality is poor and needs restoration. Hoping for a special edition soon.

We all have friends, but few are as close as Alice (Danes) and Darlene (Beckinsale). They graduated, partied, and decided to go to Bangkok together. They get caught smuggling drugs, leading to a film about survival and friendship. Brokedown Palace is a good film with outstanding acting by Danes and Beckinsale. Alice is fiery and fun but trouble-prone, while Darlene is conservative. Bill Pullman is adequate as the lawyer. The film is well-photographed, showing the hopelessness of their situation. Kaplan's direction effectively depicts the girls' daily struggle. The soundtrack, featuring Delirium and Sarah McLachlan, enhances the mood and evokes reflection on our good fortune. The girls' occasional stupidity and the seemingly less harsh prison are downsides. Overall, a great film that questions how far we'd go for a friend.

Robert Mitchum stars as Clint Tollinger, a professional town tamer, in "Man With The Gun." Tollinger arrives in a town controlled by a local gangster while searching for a former fling. As he cleans up the town, the townspeople regret hiring him due to his taxing methods. Initially an average western, the film becomes dark and character-focused. Well shot, with an enjoyable cast, Mitchum delivers a strong performance. "Man With The Gun" is a worthwhile Mitchum western.

The original Thunderbirds are iconic and loved by both kids and adults, focusing on heroic rescues and imaginative technology. This movie, however, was a poor attempt at a kids' film, filled with cartoonish elements and lacking the original's spirit. It featured uncharacteristic Kung Fu fights and mysticism, deviating from what made the original special. Ron Cook’s Parker was a highlight, but the overall film disappointed by not meeting fans' expectations. If aimed at kids, it should’ve been straight-to-video rather than misleading fans with a familiar name.

U.S. remakes of foreign films often fail, but this British remake of "Wide Awake" is awful. While "Wide Awake" is strange yet entertaining and funny, "Liam" is just strange. However, "Liam" did confirm my decision to change religions was right.

I saw this film at the NY Gay & Lesbian Film Festival and thought it was pretty bad. The slow motion and arty close-ups were distracting and pointless. The lead actor was cute but mediocre, and the rest of the cast was so-so to bad. The story was annoyingly predictable. Despite the audience's enjoyment, I disliked it a great deal.

This B-Grade movie is self-aware of its lack of credibility. The plot involves a psycho killer becoming a murderous snowman named Jack Frost after a genetic mix-up with experimental acid. Jack Frost seeks revenge on the sheriff who jailed him, killing half the town. The film lacks real scares and its effects are reminiscent of 50's B-movies, making it worth watching for a laugh. A movie to pass the time away.

I Am Curious (Yellow) was a major art-house hit, scandalous in the US when held by customs, and went to the Supreme Court. The film is daring in its attempt at a 'metafilm' while commenting on Sweden's political state. The story features Lena, a curious socialist, and her hot-cold relationship with Borje, set against Sjoman's self-inserted crew making the film. The structure mixes dramatic narrative, documentary, film-within-a-film, and even a Martin Luther King interview. Though it might not be politically coherent, its playful anarchy stands out. While emotionally lacking compared to Bergman, the film shines as an intellectual and artistic experiment in Swedish cinema. It's influential and essential for avant-garde or meta-film enthusiasts, despite some clichés and heavy-handed narration.

This movie pretends to be social commentary but is just as ridiculous as the racism it condemns. The premise: African-American = strong; any other race = weak. Ridiculous scenes include Rapaport pulling a gun, a stereotypical Jewish guy crumbling in fear, and Omar Epps standing strong. It stereotypes fraternity members and portrays a raped white girl contemplating lesbianism as a cliché. White nerds join cowardly skinheads, with Busta Rhymes unrealistically beating up a larger guy. The black characters never reject their own and dominate whites easily, leading to absurd situations. The movie is terrible, with a laughable ending. Skip this crapfest.

Probably one of the worst movies I've ever seen. The editing and sound effects were awful, with muddled talking in the background. I had to turn my volume on full blast just to hear anything, and the script was terrible. Dolph was his usual self. The villains and protagonists were bad, and overall, the movie was a stinker. Watch this to learn what NOT to do in filmmaking.

The world faces destruction, and a mission is sent to the Sun to avert it by detonating a bomb. "Solar Crisis" (1990) has a plot similar to "Sunshine," but aims to detonate a solar flare before it reaches Earth. The film is plagued by lack of urgency and momentum, with the cast, including Jack Palance, Charlton Heston, and Tim Matheson, mostly standing still in near darkness. The earthbound scenes aren't much better, featuring Matheson's son trying to reach the spaceport with Palance's crazy artist. Notable moments include a bar description of Palance and Heston firing a bazooka. The original cut had six extra minutes but is painfully boring.

"This Is Not A Love Song" brilliantly exemplifies the chase genre with a possible deeper meaning. Heaton may be in love with Spike, who is too naive to see it. Scenes like the blow back and letter writing sequences display Heaton's intimacy towards Spike. Reviews criticizing the film seem to misunderstand it, missing Heaton's possible feelings for Spike. Spike showing signs of A.D.D might be dismissed or misunderstood by some reviewers. I really enjoyed this character-focused film, although it's not for everyone. The film is grittily intense, with much dialogue between the anti-heroes post-shooting.

This new film tries to revive Laurel & Hardy with new actors but fails miserably. The out-of-place early 20th-century clothes in a 90's setting and poor dialogue contribute to this. It may be the worst film I've ever seen and should be shelved forever. The real Laurel & Hardy would be appalled.

I enjoyed this movie. The adult acting was great, though the main kid was a bit stiff but promising. The humor is subtle, unlike typical Hollywood comedies. It's slower-paced, so not for short attention spans. The Blu-ray quality is excellent with cool extras, though most deleted scenes were unnecessary.

Great for couples. As a rom-com fan, I convinced my hesitant husband to watch by mentioning it's about sport. He loved it! Drew Barrymore is hilarious, and the male lead is also great. Originally called 'The Perfect Match,' it was retitled due to another UK film. It's based on the book Fever Pitch. Highly recommended for a fun, emotional Saturday night.

This is Not a Love Song is excellent. It may not appeal to the mass public as it requires active participation, observation, and thought. Comparable to Deliverance (theme) and The Blair Witch Project (filming style), it remains unique. The cinematography (solarisation, freeze frame, blur) effectively enhances the tension. Acting is raw, menacing, and believable. The film's true theme is friendship, as hinted by the title. It is a love song.

The movie had some boring parts but the women cast, especially Krista Allen, outshone the males. Krista was seductive and sexy, making her bed scenes watchable. She also excelled in her role as the baddie. Burt Reynolds wasn't at his best and seemed to do the film for money.

This Worldwide was the cheap version of what the NWA under Jim Crockett Jr. made in the 1980s. When Ted Turner acquired NWA, he turned it into WCW and removed NWA references. NWA World Wide and NWA Pro Wrestling, rebranded with the WCW logo, moved to Disney/MGM Studios and became recap shows for WCW's Nitro, Thunder, and Saturday Night. Worldwide was the last WCW program under Turner to air before the WCW buyout by Vince McMahon and WWF. Today, the entire NWA/WCW Video Tape Library is in WWE Headquarters in Stamford, Connecticut.

I was moved by the factual basis of "Holly," but the movie didn't quite work. I look forward to the documentary by the producers, as it may be more compelling. The B-class international cast was appropriate, especially the young actress playing Holly, who did an excellent job. Ron Livingston was adequate but bland, Chris Penn was good in his final role, and Virginie Ledoyen and Udo Kier were forgettable. Despite its shortcomings, I believe in the film's message and rate it 3 stars, hoping the documentary will debut on major networks.

SEX WISH, released in the UK during the early video boom, caused a brief tabloid scandal tied to a copycat murder. Unlike tamer films of the era, it was quickly forgotten. Watching it on DVD-RW left me stunned by its demented and politically incorrect nature. The movie, a hardcore sex and violence-filled take on DEATH WISH, is deeply disturbing and far from squeamish-friendly. Memorable scenes include a rapist using a vibrator on a victim and a black couple forced to have sex before castration. Slick direction occasionally elevates it above typical grind-house fare. It's a harsh reminder that the past was far from innocent.

Eytan Fox, generally an apologist for Israeli politics, extremes this stance in "The Bubble." The screening I attended ended with quiet exits, including mine, in anger at its one-sided portrayal. The film translates self-preservation as racism and terrorism as justified anger, implying Arabs are justified in their responses. It wasn't worth the ticket price, resembling the Palestinian film "Paradise Now." Anti-Israel viewers might approve, but it's unfortunate that a talented Israeli director made such propaganda. A shameful, horrid film.

I’m open-minded about rom-coms, but this was not good. It wasn’t about comparisons to the British original; it had a meandering plot, lack of chemistry, and a terrible performance by Jimmy Fallon. Fallon plays an immature teacher, unconvincingly. His character is so irrational none could make him likable, not even reliable actors like John Cusack or Adam Sandler. Barrymore, although charming, couldn’t salvage it alone. Near the end, when she breaks up with Fallon, you cheer her decision. Sadly, plot mechanics ruin it, leaving a rational career woman chasing a childish idiot, which felt more disgusting than satisfying.

I was excited for this movie after reading the book, but it didn't meet my expectations. The characters and direction didn't fit well, and there was no real viewer connection. The dialog was inadequate, and the movie felt rushed. I was very disappointed. If you haven't read the book, it might be okay, and it could inspire you to read the book, which is more enjoyable.

This is a good movie. It's fun watching money being blown from a kid's perspective. It's a fun movie about a kid's dream coming true with $1 million. If you don't like it, don't watch it. They make movies for watchers, not complainers.

This movie, though dated, was unforgettable for me and my friends when we first watched it. Despite a feeling of disappointment upon rewatching it on DVD, it still offers valuable lessons for modern filmmakers, especially in the horror genre. The film's focus on mutilation rather than death or torture is impactful, and its morbid atmosphere remains intense throughout. While technically outdated, a remake with improved action scenes and makeup could be worthwhile, though the original's black and white tones should be preserved.

One of the worst movies ever made, but so good! Don't expect a gripping plot; you'll be disappointed. If you're in for 50 million vases and Goro's hair/bad English, it's a treat. The more you think about it, the worse it gets—unless spotting plot holes is your thing. Recommended for the bored or die-hard Smap fans. Be cautious; some Japanese fans felt Goro was selling out (thanks to producer Johnny Kitagawa).

This movie offers nothing new or worthwhile. My wife and I agreed the studio just churned it out without caring if it was entertaining. It's a "concept only" film, relying solely on its initial concept for profit. Cruella gets out of prison, supposedly adores puppies but quickly returns to her old ways. The supporting characters were irritating. Eric Idle as Waddlesworth the bird was unbearable, despite being a Python fan. Tim McInnerny and Gérard Depardieu were wasted and unfunny. Overall, it's better to let your kids watch TV than this drivel.

Edgar Rice Burroughs' non-Tarzan novel "The Lad and the Lion" was adapted into the dull 1936 movie "The Lion Man." Despite real desert locations, the film is static and slow-moving, with characters introduced only to disappear. Some characters who make an impression are played by uncredited actors. Australian actress Finis Barton stands out as a kidnapped harem girl. The cast is burdened with awkward dialogue and lacks talent, possibly due to director J.P. McCarthy's influence. Kathleen Burke and Jon Hall's performances are marginally better than Richard Carlyle's, but that's no compliment.

Bad script, direction, over-the-top performances, overwrought dialogue. For laughs, it doesn’t get better than this. Zadora’s overacting and cliched scenarios create a hilarious parody of “Hollywood.” Almost as funny as "Spinal Tap" despite not being intended as such. Don’t miss Ray Liotta’s debut line, “Looks like a penis.”

I regret buying this series. I expected more action and consistency, but it's just pure propaganda—dark, boring, and charm-less. The actors' performances are weak, especially O'Donnell, who lacks any charm. No surprise it wasn't widely shown, sold at a discount in the UK, and not released in the Netherlands.
The worst movie ever. Unwatchable and unclear if it aimed to be funny or sad. Everyone involved should be ashamed!

Starts well, but charm lost after 5 mins. Main character resembles American Pie/Loser without support or innovative plot. Heder's acting poor; Keaton, Daniels, Faris lacked substantial plot or script. Movie drags without pace or clear storyline. Predictable ending. Avoid unless absolutely nothing else to do—you'll feel cheated out of 1.5 hours.

Buster shines in this episode, showcasing the physical and silent comedy he's famous for. His gravelly voice in the talkie sequences is the only drawback. His pratfalls remain unparalleled, and he revisits gags from his early work with Roscoe Arbuckle. Thanks to Rod Serling for giving Buster's genius full scope in this touching tribute.

Monika Mitchell's showbiz satire features laughs and premeditated violence without being blood-soaked. Max Matteo (John Cassini) is a quirky actor with a poor track record for landing roles, always losing out for trivial reasons. Obsessed with eliminating the competition, he sees a rewarding career just a swing, push, and shot away. Cast includes Rene Rivera, Molly Parker, Jennifer Beals, Frank Cassini, with cameos from Eric Roberts and Sandra Oh.

Saw this movie with my rock climbing instructor, and we found it ridiculous. Stallone shouldn't carry gear if free-climbing solo, but they included dangling carabiners for effect. For those thinking Colorado looks like the Italian Dolomites (film location), Hollywood has more nonsense for you.

This movie was full of surprises! Just when you thought it couldn't get worse, they added more joints and raunchy sex scenes. We were tricked into watching it thinking it was Supervan, with promises of lasers and jail breaks. Who knew a Dollar Store Christmas present could be so much fun!

Leonard Maltin's review missed the mark, claiming the movie "starts off well then fizzles" when it actually "starts off tepid then catches fire." The plot is straightforward: a family vacation turns dire when Dad is incapacitated and Mom encounters an escaped convict while seeking help. Ralph Meeker electrifies the film halfway through as the cunning criminal, bringing reckless charm and comic friction with Barbara Stanwyck. The film has flaws, like an unbelievable scene with the police, but remains a strong thriller with an exciting conclusion.

A lonely depressed French boy Mathieu (Jeremie Elkaim) on vacation in the summer, meets and falls in love with Cedric (Stephane Rideau). The movie is quiet and slow, with constant, confusing flashbacks and plot holes. Mathieu ends up in the hospital without explanation, breaks up with Cedric while telling others he's living with him, and hooks up with another guy at the end, also unexplained. Elkaim's acting is weak, but Rideau is excellent, with great sexual magnetism. The film includes full frontal male nudity, kissing, and an explicit sex scene, showing the characters' feelings for each other. Frustrating but somewhat worth seeing, especially for Rideau's nude scenes.

The story about late 20th-century slavery from West Africa to the Arab Middle East is interesting but biased. It unfairly targets Arabs and Germans, ignoring the locals' role. Arab countries are complicit in slavery today, but so is Israel. The acting is above average, with notable performances from Peter Ustinov, Kabir Bedi, and Michael Caine.

This film transports you to a different era, showing how families dealt with war and sent young men off to fight. It's a touching look at the past and a reminder that war's casualties aren't just on the front lines. For many, it's a small thank you to past generations. Peter Outerbridge resembles a young Peter O'Toole, and Russell Crowe is charmingly Australian. His recitation of "High Flight" is worth hearing and hints at his potential with Shakespeare.

The title oversells the film's content, as there's little actual "panic in the streets." Few characters know about the murderous plague threat, but the story is suspenseful, built carefully by Elia Kazan. A highlight is the evolving relationship between Dr. Reed (Richard Widmark) and Police Captain Warren (Paul Douglas), who start off disliking each other but grow to respect one another. The performances, especially by Widmark, Douglas, and Jack Palance, are excellent. Although Barbara Bel Geddes's role is minor and somewhat flat, this is an excellent film. 9/10

Until the 1990s, there was no film adaptation of Jane Austen's "Emma". Then two arrived in 1996, and if you count 1995's "Clueless", three in two years. The story follows Emma Woodhouse, a wealthy young lady in Regency England, more focused on finding husbands for her friends than herself. She convinces Harriet to reject a proposal from a farmer for the ambitious clergyman Mr. Elton, who ends up falling for Emma, leading to complications. Kate Beckinsale, not as globally known in 1996 as Gwyneth Paltrow, shines as Emma. Beckinsale's classical role talent was evident in "Much Ado about Nothing"; Hollywood later miscast her in lesser films like "Pearl Harbor" and "Underworld." Jeremy Northam's portrayal of Mr. Knightley was more in line with the gentlemanly, chivalrous character, unlike Mark Strong's passionate lover approach. Samantha Morton fits Harriet well. While this TV adaptation has less lavish sets and fewer big names, British television excels at costume drama, making this version comparable to the cinema one. 7/10

There’s potential in this movie with a good basic idea of exploring moral issues among apocalypse survivors, but the muddled logic ruins it. The heroes are inconsistently paranoid about the airborne contagion and behave irrationally despite having survived weeks in a kill-or-be-killed world. They lack proper equipment, run out of fuel, and fail to take precautions, making their survival implausible. Chris Pine's performance as an arrogant character is unconvincing. The film looks visually impressive but is let down by weak writing and annoying characters. Even end-of-the-world genre fans should skip Carriers.

In this fascinating, dark film, a young student sells his soul to the devil for money, losing his mirror image—a visual metaphor for inner conflict. He gains wealth but loses love, haunted by his double, cut off from society like a hunted animal. Paul Wegener shines as actor and director. Despite being early and clumsy at times, its depth and tragic finale make it one of the best films ever.

Half Past Dead 2, a direct-to-video action sequel, is less entertaining than the first. It's worth a look for action movie fans, WWE star enthusiasts, or sequel lovers. Kurupt did well, Bill Goldberg was below average. The rest were just alright. Cinematography was a disaster, but the direction was acceptable. Watch it if you want; you won't lose anything either way.

"And the time came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk it took to blossom" - Anais Nin. Antwone Fisher's story, based on his autobiography "Finding Fish," is dramatized in Denzel Washington's directorial debut. It is a heartfelt, if somewhat formulaic, look at overcoming a painful past to live in the present. After outbursts at the base, Antwone (Derek Luke) is required to attend therapy sessions with Navy Psychiatrist Jerome Davenport (Denzel Washington). He recounts a traumatic childhood of abandonment and abuse in foster care. The film's strength lies in the performances of Washington and Luke, despite compressing a decade into months. With help from Davenport and his girlfriend Cheryl (Joy Bryant), Antwone gains self-esteem and returns to find his mother, seeking to complete his past. Luke's powerful performance underscores Antwone's longing for acceptance, symbolized by a dream of a loving banquet at the film's start. Antwone Fisher resonates with anyone who has felt the longing to find their way home.

Water Lilies is a French film about young female sexuality and friendship. It focuses on three middle-class teenage girls in a Paris suburb, centered around a swimming pool where two of the girls are on a synchronized water ballet team. Marie (Pauline Acquart) is enamored with Floriane (Adèle Haenel), a standout blonde team member pursued by boys. Marie drifts from her plump friend Anne (Louise Blachère), who's more accessible to boys. Floriane uses Marie as a cover for meeting boys. Marie, dazzled by Floriane, becomes her confidante. The film explores their dynamic, with Marie desiring Floriane and feeling jealousy. The girls' interactions are highlighted against an airless backdrop of water scenes. It’s the offbeat moments that bring the film to life. The film lacks big revelations but builds interest as Marie's desire for Floriane becomes evident. Anne, with a crush on Francois, faces her own challenges as boys hover on the sidelines.

Pierce Brosnan, known for his James Bond roles, seems miscast in this wilderness film. The leads, including Annie Galipeau, struggle with poorly written dialogue. While the supporting roles are well-cast, and the cinematography is beautiful, the film lacks the harsh reality of the Canadian wilderness. Galipeau's character is unconvincing and overly polished for the setting. The film also fails to capture the 1930s era it depicts, hampered by a lackluster script focused more on preaching than on plot or historical detail. Overall, the film had potential but was mishandled and protected by its environmentalist themes, making it immune to criticism.

I'm a big fan of Ashley Judd and her performance in this debut role is excellent, which is likely why critics appreciated it. However, I found the movie boring and uneventful. The plot dragged on with scenes like a shop girl idly rearranging merchandise and never delivered a dynamic moment. The cinematography and sound quality were poor, adding to the disappointment. Overall, it had zero entertainment value and felt like the longest 114 minutes of my life.

This movie was banned in England? Why? Directors like Tom Savini and George Romero have done far worse. It features typical 70s/80s horror elements: attractive girls (bad actors), a storm, a scythe, a crazy brother, and a good twist. Only about two minutes of violence and gore, and some nudity without sex. Banning it seems absurd; it could've been better with a higher budget. Entertaining but poor picture and sound quality. Banned? What a joke.

The film, surrounded by scandal, fails as a comedy, horror, and erotic movie. The 2-disc DVD has a lovely booklet and an interview with the pretentious director. The package looks great until you watch it. Disc 1 has the edited, poorly translated film with good visuals. Disc 2 holds the director's cut in French with bad quality. A hand puppet would be more effective and shocking than the actual beast.

The Hills Have Eyes II offers pure entertainment for 90 minutes, focusing on National Guard trainees battling mutated hillbillies in the desert. Expect continuous violence, blood, and a graphic rape scene. It’s decent for time-passing but drags with repetitive shocks. 4/10

It's basically the same movie with timeline mistakes, possibly due to laziness. This is a real woofer and doesn't deserve to be called a movie. I saw it as a second feature with The Boogeyman, and it was unbearable. Avoid it at all costs—it's a 0/10.

I've enjoyed many of Guy Maddin's films, but this one gave me a headache. John Gurdebeke's frenetic editing interferes with the actors. The film also seemed more brutal than Maddin's earlier work, lacking his usual humanity. The actor playing "Guy Maddin" does mimic his expressions well.

This 1939 film attempted to emulate Michael Curtiz's "Angels with Dirty Faces". Directed by Ray Enright, the only standout is the tameness of the kids compared to today's inner-city youth. Ann Sheridan and Ronald Reagan's chemistry is worth watching. The Dead End kids have bigger roles, with the plot focusing on them. Arson is depicted similarly to unscrupulous landlords in later New York. The kids seem like pranksters rather than criminals, highlighting changing times.

I like Dolph Lundgren because he shows hard work can lead to success. Detention is often dismissed, but it has some positives. An annoying teenager getting killed isn't all bad. The movie's teen stereotypes are predictable and tiresome. It would have been better if the school blew up with the writers inside. The dialogue and plot are terrible. The villains make no sense, hijacking a van full of drugs and not selling them or repainting. They kill kids and a teacher for no reason. The best part is the villains' numerous machine guns, but they miss their targets most of the time. The stunts are poor. It's surprising the movie had a $10M budget; it seems like charity work for a film school.

My first experience with a bad movie sold by a great commercial. The trailer had all the explosions and effects, some even fake. The aliens were barely shown. It felt like a scam to make money off a cheap film. That day, I learned there are bad people who make bad movies.

The review criticizes "Domino" for glorifying bounty hunting, sexism disguised as a strong female lead, and poor visuals. It slams the editing, dialogue, and Kiera Knightly's unconvincing performance. The plot distorts the real story of Domino Harvey, making it absurd, especially with unnecessary love interests and convoluted narrative. The film fails as both a comedy and an action movie, leaving the reviewer feeling sad and depressed.

I saw this movie early and expected it to be boring, hoping it would improve on the 1984 Bachelor Party. I was disappointed. Though there were some funny moments, it didn't hit the mark. The acting was OK and the storyline similar to the original, but it could have been better. It's for teens and the young at heart, full of female bodies, alcohol, and sex. Just another typical party movie. 4/10.

HUSBANDS BEWARE is a remake of BRIDELESS GROOM. The new cooking scene at the beginning is great, with the stooges always funny when they cook. After a few minutes, it cuts to original BRIDELESS GROOM footage. The 1953-1956 remakes fit with the new story, including insert shots if needed. There is also a new ending, which I won't spoil. **** out of 4 stars.

I'm glad someone exposed this movie. Bravo "The Spaz"! This is a ridiculous farce, especially for a student film! Credit to the Spazz for finding and commenting on such a rare picture. The movie follows a thin, silly storyline. Satirizing Charlie's Angels is fine, but the actresses are atrocious! The director acted, wrote, produced, and edited—he should focus on one job. Shame because he made a good movie about a killer toothbrush. Thanks to the Spazz for revealing this film; people like you are rare.

I just finished watching Going Overboard. We should send every copy of this film to Iraq. I even tried to get a blind woman to watch this and she turned it off in 20 min. Adam Sandler couldn't find a better project? The writing: those responsible should watch this movie forever in Hell. The budget was $10,000 and they were way under. Did Walmart get a good deal? Every store has a bin of this crap. The only good thing is you can use the DVD as a coaster or trade it, but then they might not be your friend anymore!

A great Classic with veteran actors, this film reflects a time in America without TV, featuring young, innocent romance differently viewed today. Ann Shirley plays an orphan called Carrot Top who is taken in by two elderly guardians in a small town. It's a down-to-earth film about decent people helping each other simply, typical of America in the 1920s and 30s, a generation that loved good family films.

Written on the Wind by Douglas Sirk engrosses viewers with its colorful, dramatic frames. The film, 99 minutes of intense family intrigue, inspired TV shows like Dallas and Dynasty. Wealth and dysfunction drive the plot: Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone as troubled heirs, with Rock Hudson and Lauren Bacall as their sane friends. Malone shines in her Oscar-winning role. Hudson and Bacall are good but overshadowed by the dramatic performances. With vibrant set-pieces, Sirk masterfully creates an extravagant late-50s melodrama.

This movie is horrendous. The acting is REALLY bad, like they're reading from a card. Painful line delivery by everyone in the cast, like a cringe-worthy high school play with weird pauses and hurried lines. The action scenes can't save it, as much of the movie is plot setup and poorly done Family Guy-style cutaways. The fight scenes are not bad, but not great, with an overly staged feel and lots of cuts. The only reason to watch is if you know someone involved in this very cheap production. The same guy wrote, directed, produced, and starred in this Middle School masterpiece.

Famous words of foreign nightclub owner Roman Maroni, that "lousy cork sucker" who spends the whole movie as Johnny Dangerously's rival and butchering the English language.

Another underrated classic found only on afternoon matinées or "Late Late Late Show"'s, Johnny Dangerously is a terrific satirical hit about a good-hearted boy leading a life of crime to help his mother and brother.

Yes, there's a story, but who cares? A cast including Joe Piscopo, Dom DeLuise, Marilu Henner, and Alan Hale Jr keeps you waiting.

Too many laughs to list. Like Airplane, pay attention or you'll miss something. Highly recommended for a good laugh!

It's like 'The Wizard of Oz,' with Paris in black-and-white and the Riviera in color. Supposedly about possessive love, destructiveness, and decadence, but really about designer gowns, Riviera shots, big cars, and music-and-dancing interludes. Watchable, but demonstrates desperate, dark plot material and glitzy style in conflict. (Was this the model for 'The Talented Mister Ripley? Anyone sense an affinity between Jean Seberg and Matt Damon?)

I wasted £10 on Attack Force. Usually, I enjoy such films, but Segal is old and bloated, the plot ludicrous, and Segal's acting dire. Half his voice was dubbed by someone sounding nothing like him. Standard action film plot, but avoid this movie like a speeding train or avian flu. Utter garbage. 1/10.

The makers did a terrific job getting you involved with the characters as they suffered. The woods scene was so superb you forget they were actors. I have never gotten so immersed in a film. Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight, along with Ned Beatty, Ronny Cox, Bill McKinney, and briefly, James Dickey, were excellent. It's somewhat disturbing, not for kids, but great dramatic cinema.

*** Spoilers*

Watched this movie over 400 times since I was 3. Grim storyline: a lamb's mother is killed by a wolf, and the lamb trains to become a wolf. After years, the lamb looks evil but can't kill other lambs and ends up killing the wolf instead. Former friends reject the lamb, and it can't return to its old life.

Beautiful art, okay songs, good voice acting.

A great masterpiece, but hard to find today.

This movie is the worst I've seen. Bad acting, script, and everything. Compared to "Cyborg" (1989) and "Nemesis" (1993), which are much better despite the same director, this film fails in story and directing. The story involves a post-apocalyptic world with cyborgs living on human blood, and a girl with a robot tasked to save mankind. The director's attempt at Hong-Kong style fighting scenes fails miserably. I recommend it only for context on "worst ever" movies. Fans should watch "Cyborg" or "Nemesis" instead. I rated it 1/10.

Pros: Nothing
Cons: Everything
Plot: A female reporter encounters a hitchhiker who tells her about zombie killings.
Review: The Zombie Chronicles is a disastrous horror movie with a $20 budget. It features forgettable actors and gross rather than frightening gore. Avoid it like a disease.
Last thoughts: Made by Brain Damage Films, fitting for such a terrible movie.
Rating: 1/10 (deserves a negative bajillion).
Cool idea... poor writing, directing, editing, and acting. Makes me wish I could strike everyone involved with lightning.

Gene Kelly, not Georges Guetary or Leslie Caron, is miscast as Jerry Mulligan, a penniless artist in Paris. Kelly's ambitious persona fails to convince as a carefree, charming character. Jerry’s actions towards Milo and Lise come off as unsavory, worsened by Caron's shy and vulnerable portrayal, making him seem creepy. The film suffers from casting older actors in roles meant for young, poor sweethearts. A younger, comedic dancer would have better suited the role, enhancing the playful pursuit and contrasting with Oscar Levant’s grumpiness. Despite these issues, the film has good points: art direction, Leslie Caron’s charm, Georges Guetary’s performance, and Nina Foch’s beauty. However, Jerry Mulligan’s character ultimately detracts from the overall experience.

Based on the infamous mass suicide incident, this 1980 TV film excellently recreates Rev. Jim Jones' life, from building a church empire to its collapse into a cult, resulting in a Congressman's assassination and 917 suicides. Tastefully yet horrifyingly done, "GUYANA TRAGEDY" stars Ned Beatty, Meg Foster, Randy Quaid, and others. Powers Boothe's riveting performance as Jim Jones stands out, making the film still notable after twenty years.

A movie that tries to be smarter than its makers. It twists through myriad plot "surprises" and steamy scenes to keep the audience guessing. James Belushi sleepwalks through it, as do the other actors. The silly and tacky plot becomes tiresome and boring, but it manages some interest in the middle. Worth a lazy watch on a boring day, but it's not a must-see. A rather lame 4!

An excellent Barbara Stanwyck double bill on one disc. The first movie, MGM's "To Please A Lady" (1950), pairs her with Clark Gable. It’s a typical star vehicle with Gable as a macho racing driver and Stanwyck as a feminist reporter. Predictably, they end up together. Gable and Stanwyck make it watchable.

The second feature, "Jeopardy" (1953), is an unknown thriller gem. Stanwyck plays a wife whose husband (Barry Sullivan) is trapped on a remote Mexican beach. An unscrupulous escaped convict (Ralph Meeker) offers help, expecting more than money. Meeker's performance is brilliant, reminiscent of Brando, but he had a so-so career. He starred in "Kiss Me Deadly" (1955) and died in 1988.

"Jeopardy" shines thanks to fine performances, John Sturges' direction, Victor Milner's cinematography, and Dimitri Tiomkin's score. Extras include a radio version of "Jeopardy" and trailers.

This disc is part of a Barbara Stanwyck box set celebrating her centenary. "Jeopardy" is an MGM winner!

I stumbled upon this film on IFC and decided to watch because of Eric Stolz and William Forsythe. The story's about a young author paralyzed in a climbing accident, recovering in a lower-class center. Written by Neal Jimenez after his own paralysis, it avoids being a manipulative tear-jerker. Patients from different backgrounds share helplessness and dependence. Stolz excels as a "lone wolf" dependent on his girlfriend (Helen Hunt); Snipes is a fine former ladies' man with a troubled family; Forsythe shines as a tough guy seeking revenge. A must-watch.

This is another tell-it-as-it-is Madhur Bhandarkar film. I find some scenes really disgusting! It tells the story of an entertainment reporter and covers the lives of those she interacts with, such as her roommates, colleagues, film stars, and more. Mrs. Iyer delivers a good performance and is noticeably de-glamorized. Madhur highlights social issues well but loses focus, leaving viewers unclear about his message. He touches on issues like child abuse, g*y folk, the unwritten Bollywood rule for women, disillusioned flight assistants, and unhappy rich families. This might be too complex for average movie-goers seeking stress relief.

This film introduced me to the U.N.C.L.E.-verse in 1972, with its debut featuring 'The Karate Killers.' I became a fan during the thrilling opening where Solo and Kuryakin's car is attacked by THRUSH mini-copters. The story follows Dr. Simon True's formula to extract gold from seawater, divided into five segments sent to his daughters worldwide. Solo and Kuryakin race to retrieve it, with cameos from Telly Savalas, Terry-Thomas, and Curt Jurgens. The formula is eventually stolen by THRUSH, who takes them to the North Pole. Despite its repetitive nature, lack of location filming, and uneven cast performances, it remains entertaining, surpassing some cinema releases of the time. Joan Crawford is hammy, Curt Jurgens miscast, Terry-Thomas charming, Herbert Lom effective, but Kim Darby as Sandy is grating. The amusing and thrilling plot leaves one curious about Solo's escape from THRUSH.

Think a talking parrot isn't for you? Think again. Paulie is filled with touching moments and lovable characters, especially Paulie himself. It's a journey worth experiencing. Don't miss it! Available on home video.

Even 9 years after the final episode, Wildside's impact lingers. Unlike other cop dramas, it stayed true to the realism of the streets and portrayed life events and characters authentically. I'm missing this series, especially compared to the over-dramatized "Underbelly." Wildside honored Sydney uniquely with A-grade acting. It's unfortunate not all actors furthered their careers. I urge the ABC to release the complete series on DVD to preserve this piece of Australian TV history.
Another great Patterson book turned into a terrible movie. If big-budget movies fail, why make an even worse low-budget TV movie? I want a good movie that does his books justice!

Lincoln’s portrayed as slow, reflecting his thoughtfulness and deliberation, making him a Great Leader civilizing the American frontier through Law. Despite historical inaccuracies, the movie offers brilliantly funny and moving moments. Highlights include Henry Fonda’s intro stroll, his visit by the river, porch dalliance with Mary Todd, and the line 'Ma'am, we've got to hurry!' The courtroom drama thins out, but Fonda remains priceless.
'The Rookie' is a wonderful movie about second chances and realizing your dreams. If you loved 'Remember the Titans', this feel-good movie is perfect for all ages. 'The Rookie' hits a major home run!

Many unfairly criticize this series, but some Guinea Pig videos are quite entertaining. Devil's Experiment has fantastic effects—realistic foot skin slice, hand breaking with a sledgehammer, and more, impressive for its vintage and low-budget. 

For those unaware, this mid-80s Japanese "extreme" fake snuff film follows a simple plot: a young girl endures brutal tortures to test her breaking point, including hot oil on her arm and maggots in a wound. 

The least effective parts are the initial unconvincing slap and kick scenes, which detract from the overall realism. 

The victim actress convincingly portrays pain and endures significant abuse on camera. Notably chilling are her reactions to loud noises, being strung up in a tree net, having guts thrown at her, and being spun in a chair forced to drink Jack Daniels until she pukes. 

I hope this helps you decide if you want to watch this episode. 8.5/10 for Devil's Experiment.

Rachel Griffiths' award-winning short film captures grief and cherishing lost loved ones in just 15 minutes. Bud Tingwell gives a touching performance as Will, a widower dealing with his wife's death and caring for her pet cow, Tulip. The film explores loneliness, responsibility, and grief with good cinematography, great direction, and superb acting. It will bring tears to anyone who has lost a loved one.

Madhur Bhandarkar's film explores Mumbai's high society with vivid characters and tabloid-style storytelling. It features a starlet discarded by a producer, a stewardess with a high-profile husband, a pedophile businessman, and more. Bhandarkar excellently digs into their lives. Strong performances by Atul Kulkarni, Boman Irani, and Sandhya Mrudul. Konkona Sen Sharma is effective, though her look could match her role better. The 140-minute film is refreshingly different and worth the money.

Cartoon Network seems desperate for ratings, canceling popular shows like Samurai Jack, Powerpuff Girls, and Dexter's Lab, and replacing them with mediocre ones. Total Drama Island and Chowder stand out, but others, like The Marvelous Misadventures of Flapjack and Johnny Test, just seem like rip-offs. Johnny Test borrows heavily from Dexter's Lab, focusing on Johnny, who harasses his twin sisters, Susan and Mary. The show lacks the charm and art style of Dexter's Lab, with annoying characters and motivations. Episodes revolve around Johnny being the twins' guinea pig, but the writing is mediocre to horrid. The show also has many cliché villains and unlikable characters, with poor voice acting. The theme song is catchy but ruined quickly. Overall, Johnny Test fails to entertain, with unappealing references, jokes, and dragging episodes. It's another poorly promoted show by Cartoon Network, better avoided in favor of something like Spongebob.

Since last September, I’ve borrowed 4-6 films weekly from the Harold Washington Library, which has a great DVD collection. Recently, I found The Short Films of David Lynch. Yesterday, I picked up Dumbland and, as a Lynch fan, it's worth the half-hour watch. The most remarkable feature is the soundtracks with their unique rhythms. Respiratory and digestive systems provide percussion; outrageous voices, violence, chirping birds, and buzzing sockets add layers. The crude animation syncs with sound, reflecting Lynch's primary interest. The shorts are odd, ugly, profound, dumb, and hilariously funny, making us ponder human absurdity. For those who enjoyed Inland Empire, Dumbland is worth it.

This remarkable film is unique, combining adult wit and humor with a fairy tale backdrop, unlike any other fantasy/sci-fi film. Its plot, performances, special effects, cinematography, and score make it incomparable. The score pulls us into the story effectively, creating the necessary awe and excitement. The film is easy to follow with compelling subplots. Wonderfully cast and superbly acted, it's the best fantasy adventure I've seen since "Return of the King." Ignore any negative reviews and enjoy one of the best movie experiences this summer!
